history.content: Math 54 background will help greatly with the linear algebra portion of EE 16A, if that's what you're trying to ask

children.subject: To qualify the student answer, 16b still expects you to know DC circuits and Op-Amps. If you do Math 54, you won't learn that material. Also, there is overlap between 54 and 16b (both do differential equations). 16a also goes into some machine learning basic stuff (e.g. least squares, OMP) from 189, so it could help to do that. If the math department allows you to waive 54 with 16a and b, I'd recommend that approach. If not, 16b and 54 would be best as even CS courses are starting to assume 16b knowledge some (namely the mathy ML ones like 127 and 189, but even courses like 106a and 106b rely on it some).

Hi! I'm not OP and am currently considering taking the 3rd approach (I took Math 54 the previous semester and have taken AP Physics C - E&M). Can you please send me all necessary materials to self-study DC circuits / Op-Amps? Really appreciate it!
The notes at the bottom of eecs16a.org contain all the information you need

^ Would highly recommend reading through the 16A notes. If you want additional notes, that I wrote when teaching / practice problems, email me at taejin@berkeley.edu, and I can send you some resources.
Thanks everyone for all the help! Really wasn't expecting to get such detailed advice I really appreciate it :)

I think this heavily depends on the background you have, and whether you've had exposure to circuits before. Just to give some background, I'm also a CS / Math double, who has taken all 3 (54/16A/16B) since I'm a senior who was not required to take 16B, but chose to out of my own interest, and have taught 16A/B for multiple semesters ever since.

From my personal experience, Math 54 was an amazing class that taught the necessary Linear Algebra background needed to go into 16B, and is taught at a slower pace than 16A, since 54 doesn't have to cover circuits. It is a very theory focused course, since it is a Math class, but it is still a lower div Math class so it will have many computational questions along with applications sprinkled here and there. On top of that, I think something that people don't discuss as much, is the fact that Math 54 covers differential equations as well. Linear Algebra is only 2/3 modules of the course. Differential equations are key to 16B, and I think 54 will give you a leg up on other students if you've had previous exposure to differential equations. My concerns for 54 however, are mainly that it is very very professor dependent. Personally I would only take 54 if it were with Nadler, Srivastava, or Ribet.

That being said, I think 16A is a great class on its own, and takes a different, applied Linear Algebra approach to the material. The core concepts of 54 such as (Gaussian Elimination, Vector Spaces, Eigenvectors, Least Squares) are all covered in 16A, but homework problems and lectures are very motivated by the applications of these concepts, whereas 54 still primarily focuses on building the theory and concepts. In 16A as well, Linear Algebra is only 2/3 modules of the course, and the other module is on Circuits. It is however, a very surface level treatment of circuits, but important concepts such as Nodal Analysis and Op-Amps are key to 16B, and assumed when walking into 16B. 

When it comes to preparation for 16B, I think either class will be fine. Math 54 will give a stronger understanding of differential equations and theory, whereas 16A will give an understanding of circuits and applications that 54 did not cover. That being said, I would also consider the fact that circuits are not all of 16B since it is only 1 module out of 4, since there are three other modules on Controls, ML, and Signals. Therefore, I would argue that having a stronger Linear Algebra / Differential Equations background is much more beneficial to succeeding in 16B. Something else to consider however, is that since 16AB is a sequence, the two courses are very similar structurally and 16B will assume students have taken 16A, and will sometimes refer back to examples or problems seen in 16A.

In an ideal world, it'd be great if students had the time to take all three, but I do understand concerns that it is one whole course of additional material that is at times redundant. Personally I'd recommend all three, since the concepts taught in all three courses are amazing, and sometimes a concept might just fly over your head without you noticing, so some redundancy can help. Therefore, I'd take the following approach:

1. Have time for all 3 (54 and 16A together, then 16B with 110 since you're doubling in Math)

2. Haven't taken Physics E&M in high school, or haven't seen circuits before (16A, then 16B )

3. Have previous exposure to circuits, and 54 has a well-rated professor (54 / 16B) (will have to self study DC circuits / Op-Amps, ask me if you need material)

4. Have previous exposure to circuits, but 54 doesn't have a well-rated professor (16A, then 16B)

I am actually doing the same thing. One thing that wasn’t mentioned much here is how the final 1/3 of 16a is machine learning, which wasn’t covered in 54 just like circuits weren’t covered. If I already learned how to do the circuits problems from the middle third of 16a, do I still need to learn he machine learning lectures too or just go right to 16b?
